tweets.text: I'm late to this, because I've been sick. I've been sick almost certainly because of the estrogen gay bombs being put into the water by the California government. Want to get in before the  @vgr 100 cap. https://t.co/2mcPc1bFd3
@vgr 1/ First off, the phrase “online conspiracy theories” implies this is something new. It isn’t. The current state is a return to a world lacking a consensual shared media reality.

@vgr 2/ The Network Era where consensus reality was owned by the 3 broadcast networks is ahistorical. We don’t live in interesting times. US origin story is a ship full of kooks sailing West because they were too extreme for both England and Holland.

@vgr 3/ The internet and cable TV before it attacked this stranglehold, by lowering the cost of broadly distributing any point of view while significantly raising the cost of maintaining general consensus.

@vgr 4/ Also during this time, the entertainment industry whose sole job is to create and sell entertainment products is massively scaling. Internet platforms modeled themselves on industry without considering the distribution of facts.
@vgr 5/ Early on, we see the growth of conspiracy and tribalism as entertainment. Tribalism used to require real commitment. Now you get tribalism for the lulz. It’s free and it’s abundant.

@vgr 6/ This, of course, came to a head in 2016 with the election of the shitposter in chief. The internet platforms quickly drew the ire of the losing side. All of a sudden, the narrative is information wars and radicalized youth.

@vgr 7/ Quick digression on the 90s. I don’t have a great thesis, but it seems relevant that after the repeal of the FCC Fairness doctrine in short order you get Rush Limbaugh, Fox News and Alex Jones.
@vgr 8/ Speaking of conservative talk radio, there should be a Kevin Bacon degrees of separation game with conspiracy theories and the Clintons. Probably a lot to unpack there.
@vgr 9/ Back to the internet, several factors seem to be reinforcing the seeming growth of online conspiracy theories. Specifically, right wing conspiracy theories.

@vgr 10/ Many “popular” conspiracies aren’t actually that popular. It’s often mainstream publications like the NYT giving new life to a YouTube video with less than 100k views because it furthers their narrative that the right is radicalizing.
@vgr 11/ The demographics for right wing conspiracy content are impossibly boring. 90% male between the ages of 18 and 30. Unsurprisingly, the same demographic consumes most online content.
@vgr 12/ The internet gives us access to the global population. As you access that large of a population, human extremes become far weirder than you can even imagine.

@vgr 13/ Rampant speculation on my part, but left-wing conspiracy theories may have a hard time getting off the ground because their audiences are so easily offended. Naïve algorithms tuned for engagement won’t take that risk.
@vgr 14/ Pause to get back to my day job.
